SubTopics: Formulate questions to focus thinking on an idea to narrow and direct further inquiry.
Content: A student is interested in learning about kangaroos and wrote the following paragraph.

:ibox:Kangaroos are a type of large mammal that lives in Australia. These creatures have large feet that help them jump up to 30 feet in a single leap. Their powerful back legs and a long, strong tail help them to jump. In the wild, kangaroos live in small groups of around 50 animals.
Which question should the student use to find more information about kangaroos to include in the paragraph?

A.Choice: Why do kangaroos live in groups?

B.Choice: Can a person keep a kangaroo as a pet?

C.Choice: Do other animals live in the area of Australia where kangaroos live?

D.Choice: What are other types of animals besides kangaroos that move by jumping?

SubTopics: Organize and categorize important information; collaborate to validate or revise thinking; report relevant findings.
Content: A student is doing research on sea turtles. Read the paragraph from the source.

:ibox:Sea turtles lay eggs. A mother turtle finds a place on land to make a nest. She digs a hole in the sand or dirt on a beach, lays her eggs, and then buries them. The mother leaves the eggs and returns to the water. Weeks later, the eggs hatch. The baby turtles climb out of the nest and make their way to the ocean. They must avoid predators, such as sea birds. If these newborn turtles make it to the ocean, they start a “swimming frenzy” to move miles away into deeper waters.
If the student used information from this source, which title would best describe the topic of the report?

A.Choice: Sea Turtles Love to Swim

B.Choice: Life Begins for Sea Turtles

C.Choice: Sea Turtle Nests

D.Choice: How to Find Sea Turtle Eggs

SubTopics: Ask and answer literal and inferential questions to determine meaning; refer explicitly to the text to support inferences and conclusions.
Content: Why does Sarah move over to the larger rock in the stream?

A.Choice: She thinks she might have better luck finding gold there.

B.Choice: She needs more space to spread out her supplies.

C.Choice: She hopes she will be able to keep herself clean.

D.Choice: She wants to try working without her brother.

SubTopics: Determine the theme by recalling key details that support the theme.
Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the theme that sometimes things work out better than expected?

A.Choice: Sarah bounced excitedly down the narrow trail after her brother Ben.

B.Choice: He had helped his father and some other adults look for gold in a spot up the river, but this was the first time Sarah had been allowed to go.

C.Choice: “If we find something that looks important, we'll take it home to ask if it is real or if it is just fool's gold,” he suggested.

D.Choice: “You're not so bad to have around, you know.”

SubTopics: Describe characters’ traits, motivations, and feelings and explain how their actions contribute to the development of the plot.
Content: Which sentences from the passage BEST show that Ben is unhappy that he had to bring his sister with him? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: Ben whistled ahead of her, carrying his cloth sack of equipment over his shoulder.

B.Choice: He hoped his sister would not interfere with his work.

C.Choice: With only a hint of impatience, Ben took a deep breath and demonstrated for her.

D.Choice: “That is where small pieces of gold can sometimes be found,” he explained.

E.Choice: Encouraged, he grabbed his pan and started working alongside her.

SubTopics: Identify and explain how the author uses idioms, metaphor, or personification to shape meaning and style.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:ibox:Even though Sarah was excited, part of her feared that she may not be cut out for panning.
What does the phrase “may not be cut out for” tell the reader about Sarah?

A.Choice: The phrase shows that Sarah does not really want to learn how to pan for gold.

B.Choice: The phrase shows that Sarah realizes her brother does not believe she will be helpful.

C.Choice: The phrase shows that Sarah suspects the activity will not be as much fun as she hoped.

D.Choice: The phrase shows that Sarah is worried she will not have enough skills to pan for gold.

SubTopics: Explain how the author’s choice of words, illustrations, and conventions combine to create mood, contribute to meaning, and emphasize aspects of a character or setting.
Content: Read the paragraph from the passage.

:ibox:After a while, Sarah noticed her brother staring silently at the water. She could tell that he was frustrated that he was not finding anything. But Sarah did not get upset. Instead, she continued to search the sandy stream thoroughly. Sarah was determined to give her brother a reason to be proud of her, not make him annoyed that she came along.
How does the author's choice of words contribute to meaning in the passage?

A.Choice: It shows that Sarah is less worried about getting dirty than Ben is.

B.Choice: It shows how much Sarah cares about the way Ben feels about her.

C.Choice: It shows that Sarah is more unsure about her task than Ben is.

D.Choice: It shows how much Sarah hopes she will find gold before Ben finds gold.

SubTopics: Use paragraph-level context to determine the meaning of words and phrases.
Content: Read the paragraph from the passage.
:ibox:He then handed the pan to Sarah. “Swirl it with your hand until the sand settles on the bottom and the water is on top,” he i͟n͟s͟t͟r͟u͟c͟t͟e͟d, enjoying the role of expert.
What does the word i͟n͟s͟t͟r͟u͟c͟t͟e͟d mean as it is used in the paragraph?

A.Choice: dared

B.Choice: directed

C.Choice: warned

D.Choice: worried

SubTopics: Ask and answer literal and inferential questions to determine meaning; refer explicitly to the text to support inferences and conclusions.
Content: According to “Possible Pets,” what is a likely reason why a person would choose a fish rather than a dog?

A.Choice: The person does not have a lot of time to spend with a pet.

B.Choice: The person hopes to have several different kinds of pets.

C.Choice: The person wants a pet that enjoys being around people.

D.Choice: The person prefers pets that do not stay inside the house.

SubTopics: Ask and answer literal and inferential questions to determine meaning; refer explicitly to the text to support inferences and conclusions.
Content: In “Preparing a Happy Home: A Kitten's Journal,” why does Fluffy stay inside the house?

A.Choice: Fluffy is still too young to go outside.

B.Choice: Fluffy is happier inside a sunny room.

C.Choice: Ellen believes Fluffy will live longer inside.

D.Choice: Scout will chase Fluffy if they are outside.

SubTopics: Ask and answer literal and inferential questions to determine meaning; refer explicitly to the text to support inferences and conclusions.
Content: This question has two parts. First, answer part A. Then, answer part B.
In “Preparing a Happy Home: A Kitten's Journal,” how can the reader tell that Fluffy wants all kittens to have a safe and happy life?

A.Choice: Fluffy describes how dogs may get along with a kitten.

B.Choice: Fluffy describes how the Jacksons got a new kitten.

C.Choice: Fluffy provides information so that other owners will know how to care for a kitten.

D.Choice: Fluffy provides information on what went wrong when the Jacksons first got their kitten.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer in part A?

A.Choice: Then when I was about 10 weeks old, a family came and scooped me up and took me home with them.

B.Choice: Even though I did not like Scout at first, he and I have become good friends.

C.Choice: The Jacksons did make a few mistakes when they first brought me home.

D.Choice: I know this is a long list of tasks, but remember, if treated well, your kitten will become your best and most loving friend.

SubTopics: Explain how the author uses words and phrases to inform, explain, or describe.
Content: Read the sentences from “Possible Pets.”
:ibox:Some cats have long hair, while others have short hair. Some cat breeds, like the Sphynx, have no hair at all. Cats can have thin tails or puffy tails. One type of cat, the Manx, has no tail.
What do the author's words help the reader to understand?

A.Choice: that cats need to be brushed often

B.Choice: that cats come from different places

C.Choice: that cats enjoy attention from humans

D.Choice: that cats can have different appearances

SubTopics: Use knowledge of appendices, timelines, maps, and charts to locate information and gain meaning; explain how these features contribute to a text.
Content: How do the lists contribute to meaning in BOTH passages?

A.Choice: They both provide information about how to prepare a pet for a trip to see a veterinarian.

B.Choice: They both draw the reader's attention to important information about pets.

C.Choice: They both provide steps to follow when bringing a pet home from the shelter.

D.Choice: They both draw the reader's attention to how many different types of pets are available.

SubTopics: Use paragraph-level context to determine the meaning of words and phrases.
Content: Read the paragraph from “Preparing a Happy Home: A Kitten's Journal.”

:ibox:So, when I want to see birds or bugs, I just walk through the little door from our living room to the e͟n͟c͟l͟o͟s͟e͟d porch. The porch has windows all the way around. Sometimes I sit for hours on that porch watching the wrens, bluebirds, and cardinals. This way, I am safe from the outdoors but can still enjoy birdwatching.
Which words in the paragraph help the reader understand the meaning of the word e͟n͟c͟l͟o͟s͟e͟d?

A.Choice: want to see

B.Choice: has windows all the way around

C.Choice: sit for hours

D.Choice: can still enjoy birdwatching

SubTopics: State the author’s purpose; distinguish one’s own perspective from that of the author.
Content: What is the purpose of BOTH passages?

A.Choice: to explain why people should keep their pets inside

B.Choice: to tell people to choose a pet that can be left alone for a long time

C.Choice: to help people gather information before getting a family pet

D.Choice: to remind people to take pets for regular walks to keep them healthy

SubTopics: Introduce the topic or text, state an opinion, and create an organizational structure that includes reasons.
Content: A student is writing an opinion paper about watching television. Read the opinion.

:ibox:Many adults think that children spend too much time watching TV, but not all TV shows are bad. There are many television programs that are educational. People can learn about places they have never been, discover facts about animals, or even learn how to cook! TV can also be entertaining. Watching shows that are funny or exciting is a perfect way for people to relax. These are just a few of the benefits of watching TV. So, next time you tune in to your favorite show, think about all the interesting things you are learning.
Which sentence should be included in the writing to clearly state the student's opinion about television?

A.Choice: I have learned lots of information by watching TV.

B.Choice: Many adults think that watching TV is a waste of time.

C.Choice: Most children enjoy watching educational TV programs.

D.Choice: I believe watching TV can actually be good for children.

SubTopics: Introduce a topic and group related information together.
Content: A student is writing about reptiles. Read the draft.

:ibox:Many people get these two reptiles confused. Although they look similar, there are a few easy ways to tell these two animals apart.

One of the main ways to identify these animals is to look at the shape of their heads. Alligators have shorter, wider heads than crocodiles. An alligator's head is shaped like the letter U, while a crocodile's head is more pointy or V-shaped.

Another way to identify these animals is to look at the color of their skin. Both animals are covered with hard dry scales, but an alligator's skin appears much darker in color than a crocodile's skin.
Which sentence would BEST introduce the topic?

A.Choice: Did you know that alligators and crocodiles are both reptiles?

B.Choice: Can you tell the difference between an alligator and a crocodile?

C.Choice: Alligators and crocodiles have lived on Earth for a very long time.

D.Choice: Alligators and crocodiles are some of the most feared animals on Earth.

SubTopics: Develop the topic with facts, definitions, and details.
Content: student is writing a report about animals in winter. The student wants to develop the ideas in the report. Read the report.

:ibox:What do you do when the weather turns cold? Do you put on warmer clothes or snuggle up in a warm blanket? Animals must prepare for cold weather too. Some animals hibernate or go into a deep sleep in the winter. Bears, groundhogs, and turtles are among the many animals that sleep during the winter months. But not all animals hibernate. T͟h͟e͟r͟e͟ ͟a͟r͟e͟ ͟o͟t͟h͟e͟r͟ ͟w͟a͟y͟s͟ ͟t͟h͟a͟t͟ ͟a͟n͟i͟m͟a͟l͟s͟ ͟p͟r͟e͟p͟a͟r͟e͟ ͟f͟o͟r͟ ͟c͟o͟l͟d͟ ͟w͟e͟a͟t͟h͟e͟r͟.
Which sentence BEST supports the underlined sentence?

A.Choice: Many squirrels are unable to find food during the winter.

B.Choice: Some bears remain in a deep sleep throughout the winter.

C.Choice: Many birds travel to warmer places in the winter.

D.Choice: Most animals wake from their winter naps in early months of spring.

SubTopics: Capitalize appropriate words in titles, historical periods, company names, product names, and special events.
Content: Which book title has the correct capitalization?

A.Choice: Lion has a loud Roar

B.Choice: On the journey to California

C.Choice: Monkey Fun At The Zoo

D.Choice: Adventures in Space Travel

SubTopics: Quotation marks to mark direct speech.
Content: Read the sentences.
:ibox:“I have a good idea!” Let's have ice cream after dinner, said Joey.
Which revision corrects the punctuation mistake in the sentences?

A.Choice: “I have a good idea! Let's have ice cream after dinner, said Joey.”

B.Choice: “I have a good idea! Let's have ice cream after dinner,” said Joey.

C.Choice: I have a good idea! “Let's have ice cream after dinner,” said Joey.

D.Choice: I have a good idea! Let's have ice cream after dinner, “said Joey.”
